Superman star Christopher Reeve isn't expecting to walk once more as soon as he'd expected. I am now on a plan where if I operate very, very hard, I may be able to get off this hose within a yr," he said. "That will be a gift because, you understand, this is not a very nice necktie." CBS News Correspondent Rick Stewart reports with no sight of the fugitive aboveground, agents are now systematically going subterranean picking their approach through the hundreds of caves that dot the area. A CBS cameraman lately went along and the pictures speak by themselves. The terrain on the surface was as thicker as a jungle. Brokers report encountering bots the size of a hand as well as rattlesnakes as fat like a man's arm. Mature investigators now compare searching for Rudolph to overcome duty in terms of strain. Many agents have experienced to order new boot styles after their old ones began to rot under the harsh conditions and also the FBI and ATF have started to rotate much of his or her force in order to give veterans on the 200-man job force a much-needed bust. As for Rudolph there is a increasing belief that he may, the truth is, be in one of these caves. Finding the right one, nonetheless will be no easy process. CBS News Richard Schlesinger reports.This summer, Abc will drop Sixteen castaways on a deserted exotic island in the To the south China Sea. Right now there, they'll fend off deadly coral snakes, construct shelters, forage for foodstuff, and set up their own miniature society and also government, all as you watch comfortably at home. It's called Survivor . It appears a little like the classic hidden-camera show, Candid Camera . Only on Heir , the cameras will not be hidden. All the members agree ahead of time to be able to broadcast their entire lives for 100 nights. It's designed to be part real-life drama along with part game demonstrate.One by one, people will become voted off the area by their housemates as well as viewers. The last one standing wins $1 million."We're calling that 'reality-variety,'" says Ben Silverman from the William Morris Agency, "because it is putting these people in just a context and an surroundings and then letting them go." Survivor is founded on a Dutch present called Big Brother . CBS has paid big bucks to bring a form of Big Brother to the U.S., hoping it will be the next big thing.Why would viewers need to see strangers fight for his or her lives on prime moment? Robert Thompson, a tutor at Syracuse University's Center for that Study of Well-known Television, suggested, "This interests a part of us i don't think we really want to admit is there."For each of the problems, ethical as well as everything else, there's something this is a little bit exciting,Inches said Thompson.Besides, overseas shows are all the rage in American community TV these days, especially after the success of ABC's Who Wants To Be described as a Millionaire , which is based on a British program.
